show.title: VHYes
show.headline: Press play on this offbeat coming-of-age comedy

event.title: <show-title>VHYes</show-title> <event-type-title>w/Live Q&A</event-type-title>
event.headline: A found footage kaleidoscope, with cast & filmmakers in-person!
event.description:
A bizarre retro comedy shot entirely on VHS, VHYES takes us back to a simpler time, when 12-year-old Ralph mistakenly records home videos and his favorite late-night shows over his parents’ wedding tape. The result is a nostalgic wave of home shopping clips, censored pornography, and nefarious true-crime tales that threaten to unkindly rewind Ralph’s reality.

The crew of VHYES will join us for an in-person Q&A. Producer Delaney Schenker will attend the Q&As in Austin, and will be joined by filmmaker Jack Henry Robbins in NYC, DC, San Francisco, and L.A. Thomas Lennon will also join the Q&A in L.A.

Screening courtesy of Oscilloscope Laboratories

show.title: Popstar: Never Stop Never Stopping
show.headline: Doink de doink!

event.title: <show-title>Popstar: Never Stop Never Stopping</show-title> <event-type-title>Movie Party</event-type-title>
event.headline: Let us see that donkey roll
event.description:
With a hilarious lead performance from Andy Samberg, tons of killer cameos including Maya Rudolph, Sarah Silverman, Usher, and Adam Levine’s hologram (so expensive!), and plenty of big laughs & bumpin’ tunez, POPSTAR has established itself as a modern cult classic.

That’s why we’re inviting you to kick it with the boyz of The Lonely Island at the most baller Movie Party of all time (#sohumble). We’ll have onscreen lyrics so you can get in on the jamz, some extremely humble sunglasses, “gold” necklaces to show you’re a ride-or-die Connor4Real fan, a tattoo honoring the greatest turtle to ever live, and a Party Wolves business card (DO NOT pay for them to come to this event). And be sure to show up early for our Show Pony drawing contest before the film.

So bring your crew, show us your Donkey Roll, and never stop never stopping at our POPSTAR Movie Party. DOINK DE DOINK!

event.description:
Warm up those pipes and join us for our WICKED Sing-Along screening, complete with onscreen lyrics. Whether you can really nail “Popular” or regularly defy gravity, you and your fellow Ozians can be the star of the show alongside your favorite witches.

Please note that our usual No Talking/No Singing Showtunes policy is relaxed for this screening, but let’s keep it fun and not get carried away.

show.title: Cries and Whispers
show.headline: Liv Ullmann shines in Ingmar Bergman's existential drama.

event.title: <show-title>Cries and Whispers</show-title>
event.headline: Robert Eggers personally recommends Ingmar Bergman's existential drama
event.description:
Presented in Swedish with English subtitles

CRIES AND WHISPERS is presented here as part of our Robert Eggers Guest Selects for influencing his new film, NOSFERATU. “CRIES AND WHISPERS by Ingmar Bergman is perhaps my favorite Bergman film. It’s also, you know, one of the best horror films ever made, even though it certainly doesn’t try to be one and wouldn’t be classified as one.” – Robert Eggers.

This existential wail of a drama from Ingmar Bergman concerns two sisters, Karin (Ingrid Thulin) and Maria (Liv Ullmann), keeping vigil for a third, Agnes (Harriet Andersson), who is dying of cancer and can find solace only in the arms of a beatific servant (Kari Sylwan). An intensely felt film that is one of Bergman’s most striking formal experiments, CRIES AND WHISPERS (which won an Oscar for the extraordinary color photography of Sven Nykvist) is a powerful depiction of human behavior in the face of death, positioned on the borders between reality and nightmare, tranquillity and terror. (Janus Films)

contentBlocks.paragraphs:
Presented in Swedish with English subtitles

CRIES AND WHISPERS is presented here as part of our Robert Eggers Guest Selects for influencing his new film, NOSFERATU. “CRIES AND WHISPERS by Ingmar Bergman is perhaps my favorite Bergman film. It’s also, you know, one of the best horror films ever made, even though it certainly doesn’t try to be one and wouldn’t be classified as one.” – Robert Eggers.

show.title: Death Becomes Her
show.headline: Keep young and beautiful – or die trying!

event.title: <show-title>Death Becomes Her</show-title>
event.headline: Goldie Hawn & Meryl Streep slay the screen in this 1992 fatal femme cult classic
event.description:
“Now, a warning…”

What would you do to stay young forever? This is an evergreen question in many cinematic and literary explorations, from Oscar Wilde to the copious vampire narratives we consume, from THE SUBSTANCE to Korean skincare TikToks hocking the perfect recipe for “glass skin,” we are a species obsessed with delaying time's inevitable progression. Robert Zemeckis’ 1992 black comedy (co-written by Journeymen screenwriter David Koepp and Martin Donovan) DEATH BECOMES HER is a classic example of this trope played out in gloriously campy fashion. Goldie Hawn and Meryl Streep are Helen Sharp and Madeline Ashton, two frenemies who compete in all things, especially for the attention and affection of dopey plastic surgeon Ernest Menville (played against type by a delightful Bruce Willis). When presented with a method of reversing and halting their aging by the gorgeous and mysterious vamp Lisle Von Rhuman (THE ICON Isabella Rosellini) both women seize the clandestine opportunity, and from there, things get grim and zany. Overflowing with subtextual sapphic angst and seething with a deep investment in the emasculation of cis straight men, this movie is a freaking blast! Groundbreaking Acadamy Award-winning special effects and hilarious performances from its entire cast helped launch DEATH BECOMES HER to cult classic status (especially amongst queer audiences) despite mixed reviews from critics. As Madeline would say, “Screw the critics” – this movie is a STAR! Help us kick off the 2025 season of Queer Film Theory 101 with a dose of the potion with the motion. Stay beautiful, queerdos (but then again, you always are.)

show.title: Mirror
show.headline: Tarkovsky’s non-linear look back on life in Russia before, during, & after WWII

event.title: <show-title>Mirror</show-title>
event.headline: RaMell Ross personally recommends Andrei Tarkovsky's striking slice of life
event.description:
MIRROR is presented here as part of our RaMell Ross Guest Selects for influencing his new film, NICKEL BOYS. “Andrei Tarkovsky’s THE MIRROR is a phenomenal piece of sensory poetry. It reminds me so much of the way the mind works, or at least my mind works, maybe at its best and simultaneously at its worst.” – RaMell Ross.

Andrei Tarkovsky creates a moving and personal piece of lyrical filmmaking with this striking, non-linear look back on life in Russia before, during, and after the Second World War. “For the first time,” Tarkovsky says of MIRROR, “I would use the means of cinema to talk of all that was most precious to me, and do so directly, without playing any kind of tricks.” Tarkovsky needed 20 rough cuts before arriving at the film’s intricately interflowing system of flashbacks and archival footage, often interpreted as unfolding in a dying artist’s final rays of consciousness.

contentBlocks.paragraphs: MIRROR is presented here as part of our RaMell Ross Guest Selects for influencing his new film, NICKEL BOYS. “Andrei Tarkovsky’s THE MIRROR is a phenomenal piece of sensory poetry. It reminds me so much of the way the mind works, or at least my mind works, maybe at its best and simultaneously at its worst.” – RaMell Ross.

show.title: Persona (1966)
show.headline: Ingmar Bergman's most personal and original film

event.title: <show-title>Persona (1966)</show-title>
event.headline: Almodóvar & Swinton personally recommend Ingmar Bergman's dreamlike visual poem
event.description:
Presented in Swedish with English subtitles

PERSONA is presented here as part of our Pedro Almodóvar/Tilda Swinton/Julianne Moore Guest Selects for influencing their new film, THE ROOM NEXT DOOR. “This sense of two women being in such a liaison that they kind of become, if not one, they become a sort of melange of two souls was really what we wanted to look at and PERSONA is the masterpiece in this regard.” – Tilda Swinton.

By the mid-'60s, Ingmar Bergman had already conjured many of the cinema’s most unforgettable images. But with the radical PERSONA, this supreme artist attained new levels of visual poetry. In the first of a series of legendary performances for Bergman, Liv Ullmann plays a stage actor who has inexplicably gone mute; an equally mesmerizing Bibi Andersson is the garrulous young nurse caring for her in a remote island cottage. While isolated together there, the women perform a mysterious spiritual and emotional transference that would prove to be one of cinema’s most influential creations. Acted with astonishing nuance and shot in stark contrast and soft light by the great Sven Nykvist, PERSONA is a penetrating, dreamlike work of profound psychological depth. (Janus)

contentBlocks.paragraphs:
Presented in Swedish with English subtitles

show.title: Born Innocent: The Redd Kross Story
show.headline: A story of one of the most important alternative rock bands

landscapeHeroImage.altText: BORN INNOCENT: THE REDD KROSS STORY

portraitHeroImage.altText: BORN INNOCENT: THE REDD KROSS STORY

posterImages.altText: BORN INNOCENT: THE REDD KROSS STORY

event.title: <show-title>Born Innocent: The Redd Kross Story</show-title><event-type-title> with Live Q&A</event-type-title>
event.headline: Live Q&A with the McDonald brothers and director Andrew Reich
event.description:
In-person Q&A with band members Jeff and Steve McDonald and director Andrew Reich

BORN INNOCENT makes the case for Redd Kross as the seminal West Coast band of the last half-century. Their influence reaches across the genres of punk, college rock, grunge, metal, and indie rock. Long a “secret handshake” favorite of true music fans, it’s time for the world to discover the joyful and irresistible music of the McDonald brothers.

show.title: Hippo
show.headline: A hormone-fueled, tragicomic waking nightmare of step-siblings Hippo & Buttercup

event.title: <show-title>Hippo</show-title><event-type-title> with Live Q&A</event-type-title>
event.headline: Live Q&A with the cast and crew
event.description:
Director/co-writer Mark H. Rappaport will attend the live Q&As in Austin and New York City. Joining Rappaport in NYC are actor/co-writer Kimball Farley and cinematographer William Babcock, moderated by executive producer David Gordon Green. Actor Eliza Roberts will attend the live Q&A in Los Angeles.

HIPPO examines the coming-of-age of two step-siblings: Hippo, a video-game-addicted teenager, and Buttercup, a Hungarian-Catholic immigrant with a love of classical music and Jesus. Like the Ancient Greek Aphrodite, Buttercup’s love is unrequited by a brother who prefers to indulge in the art of war and chaos.

show.title: Hot Rod
show.headline: Smack destiny in the face

event.title: <show-title>Hot Rod</show-title> <event-type-title>Movie Party</event-type-title>
event.headline: Our most stunt-y, daredevil-y movie party ever
event.description:
Who wants to see us throw a big-ass movie party?!

If that sounds like cool beans to you, then join us for HOT ROD, the supremely goofy cult classic about a small-town stuntman from the guys of The Lonely Island.

We think it’s absurdist perfection, so put on your most patriotic jumpsuit and strap in for a movie party for all you daredevils out there. We’ll have custom bandanas, fake mustaches (all great men have them), and even different spirit animals so you can choose the one that best represents you while you live your dream of feeling like a stuntperson without having to actually do any, you know, stunts.

So if you like to party, join us for a daring, action-packed movie party celebrating one of the most underrated comedies ever made.

marketStrings.value: The personal closed captioning device displays feature film dialogue and other audio in the form of English-language text for individuals who are deaf or hard of hearing.

The descriptive audio headset provides individuals who are blind or have low vision with an English-language narration of the details of the feature presentation that can't be understood by the soundtrack alone.

Upon request at the box office, we provide assistive listening headsets with amplified audio for those individuals who are hard of hearing. For guests who prefer to use their own hearing aids, neck loops, or cochlear implants, our assistive listening headsets have a 3.5mm headphone jack to connect to those devices.

In order to ensure the highest quality experience for all guests, you may not enter a movie after it has started. We’d love to see you up to 30 minutes early. Running late? No worries, we will happily exchange your ticket for a different showtime or a raincheck to a future show.

sessionAttributes.name: Baby Day Show
sessionAttributes.description: For our baby day shows, we keep the lights up a bit, and the sound down a bit, so your little one never has to know they even went to the movies!

sessionAttributes.name: Kid Friendly
sessionAttributes.description: Grab the fam and let the fun begin! Our Kid Friendly screenings include pre-show activity sheets and crayons, a relaxed noise policy, and kids menus. Ages 3+ welcome with a parent or guardian.

agePolicies.description: All minors under the age of 18 must be accompanied by an adult. Children ages 6+ admitted. Children 5 and under (including infants) are ONLY admitted during specifically designated "All Ages" and "Family Friendly" screenings.
